title: 108_hr2539
content:
The "Violence Against Children Act of 2003" may be cited as such. Congress finds that children under 18 make up a significant portion of crime victims, with high rates of sex crimes and kidnapping. They are also more likely to be victims of violent crime compared to adults. Many crimes against children go unreported, leading to long-lasting negative effects such as delayed development and substance abuse. Lack of resources in local agencies hinders their ability to protect children and families in need. Failure to pay child support is considered a form of neglect. Failure to pay child support is a form of neglect, leading to children living in poverty and lacking education, healthcare, and housing. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN

SEC. 101. ENHANCED PENALTIES. Title I of the United States Code is amended to include a new section, 2260A, which addresses violence against children. It outlines penalties for those who willfully injure or attempt to injure individuals under 18 years of age, including imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. More severe penalties apply if the offense results in death, involves kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder. The circumstances under which these penalties apply include instances where the offense occurs during travel by the defendant or victim. The new section 2260A of Title I of the United States Code addresses violence against children, outlining penalties for those who harm individuals under 18 years old. The penalties apply if the offense occurs during travel across state lines, using interstate commerce, or involves certain weapons. Offenses under this section are subject to penalties in section 1111 of the title. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for federal crimes against children under 18. The Comptroller General will review state laws on crimes against children and report findings to Congress. Additionally, there will be enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. SEC. 102 of the bill provides enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General will offer technical, forensic, and prosecutorial support for crimes of violence or felonies committed against individuals under 18 years of age. Priority will be given to crimes involving offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states and rural jurisdictions facing financial challenges in investigating or prosecuting the crime. TITLE II--GRANT PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children. Grants provide personnel, training, technical assistance, and equipment for apprehension and prosecution of offenders. Training for law enforcement, prosecutors, and judges is emphasized, along with developing specialized units and implementing effective policies for preventing and responding to crimes against children. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, focusing on prevention, identification, and response to such crimes. This includes developing data collection systems, enhancing collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies, and addressing the needs of Indian tribes in dealing with crimes against children. Each State, Indian tribal government, or unit of local government seeking a grant must submit an application to the Attorney General. Each State, Indian tribal government, or unit of local government must submit an application to the Attorney General for a grant to address crimes against children. The application must include the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant funds, as well as consultation with nonprofit organizations. The State, Indian tribal government, or unit of local government must consult with nonprofit victim services programs and certify the proper use of Federal funds for activities related to crimes against children. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 for this purpose. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for seminars, hotlines, training programs, informational materials, intervention services, awareness efforts, emergency medical treatment, and counseling for victims and their families. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for increasing awareness in underserved communities, emergency medical treatment, counseling for victims and their families, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in victims of crimes against children. States, tribal governments, local governments, or organizations seeking grants must submit an application outlining the grant's purposes and intended use of funds. The grant application must describe the purposes, intended use of funds, and expected results. It should also demonstrate consultation with victim services programs for crimes against children. The grant application must describe the purposes, use of funds, and expected results, as well as consultation with victim services programs for crimes against children. Organizations must have experience in providing services related to crimes against children and certify that federal funds will supplement non-federal funds. The grant application must detail the purposes, fund usage, and outcomes, including consultation with victim services for crimes against children. Organizations need experience in this area and must ensure federal funds supplement non-federal funds. The General can waive requirements for NGOs in exceptional cases. Authorization of $25,000,000 is allocated annually from 2004 to 2008 for this section. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT.

Each State receiving grants must establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING.

States must utilize the National Incident-Based Reporting System for statistical data collection.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN. Each State receiving grants under section 202 must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn with a hospital employee anonymously, collect family medical history with approval, search missing person databases, and publicize the Safe Haven law within 3 years. Exceptions may apply if the newborn shows signs of abuse. State statutes may allow parents to leave a newborn anonymously with no penalty, except if the baby shows signs of abuse or intentional harm. SEC. 304. IMPROVED CHILD PROTECTION SERVICES PROGRAMS. States receiving funding for child welfare services must submit a report on their programs within 180 days. The General Accounting Office will also report to Congress on State practices and policies, including record-keeping and well-being verification for children in care. States are monitoring the whereabouts of children in their care, evaluating the effectiveness of the review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, implementing best practices, and providing recommendations for legislative changes to Congress. TITLE IV--CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT

SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend the current Federal tax treatment on bad debt to nonpayment of child support by allowing deductions for unpaid child support and requiring unpaid amounts to be added to income for tax purposes.
